name: TheAtlantic
text: In 2020 and in 1864, the United States "managed to avoid a descent into immediate catastrophe," @ClintSmithIII writes. But the elections' narrow margins “should make Americans wary of any notion that this country glides … along a natural arc of progress.” https://t.co/9lFB4TCuBN

name: TheAtlantic
text: Readers respond to recent stories in @theatlantic magazine. https://t.co/f4UdNPMukb

name: TheAtlantic
text: Joe Biden "will begin his term in a very different world than when he was vice president or a senator," @thomaswright08 writes: https://t.co/wN2Y396TAD

name: TheAtlantic
text: Is it still possible to teach children how to make a Republican friend or a Democratic friend on the playground? @emmaogreen talks with the editor in chief of "Highlights": https://t.co/Dl3lp9nBEV

name: TheAtlantic
text: Naomi Shihab Nye's “Darling”  acknowledges the pain that can come with feeling split between places—disconnected from a part of yourself, like a phantom limb. https://t.co/XThqK6RuXH

name: TheAtlantic
text: “Murphy, who will turn 60 next year, was more than a star in the 1980s, the decade in which he emerged,” @MrKamp writes. Now the comedian “has made a conscious and fairly recent decision to whip himself back into peak-Eddie shape.” https://t.co/4me6Dsva3A

name: TheAtlantic
text:
Watching the person you love wither away slowly is painful enough in “normal” times, Hisham Melhem writes. During a pandemic, it's cruel.
https://t.co/gURo17Flbp
